WRITING.TEXT: Again, it's not the women who made the film, it's a competition piece and something a film maker did in accordance with the rules to the competition. It wasn't a vid about the product (quite possibly the op is to "blame" for making it sound that it's a vid about invisible helmets, again, if any blame is to be dispensed). The director most likely had loads of tidbits from interviews to choose from, and this is how he edited it, including choosing the "cheesy music". Perhaps it's because I'm Swedish and understood, not reading the subtitles; they are not bragging, they are telling a story about having an idea that some people believed in enough to invest capital in, even though once some geezer figured they'd be needing a man to run such a project. What's ridiculously over the top is the critique of the women (sooo typical women-type of comments), and that makes it misogony, I'm afraid.

Please note that this film is entered into a film competition, where the general idea is to present the people behind ideas. [Here you'll find a film](http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_kZGTOLBvek) released about a year ago showing the product.

You all reason like it's the girls in the video's choice to present them like that? It would appear to me that the producer of the segment are to "blame" if any is to be dispensed. He entered this short in a [competition](http://focusforwardfilms.com/films/49/), called Focus Forward Films.
I thought it was clever of her - it's either trying to read or work on a laptop, is the impression I've gotten.

There are three different translations of the poem, [David McDuff](http://www.karinboye.se/verk/dikter/dikter-mcduff/in-motion.shtml), [Jenny Nunn](http://www.karinboye.se/verk/dikter/dikter-engelska/on-the-move.shtml), and [Hans Corell](http://www.karinboye.se/verk/dikter/dikter-engelska/on-the-move-2.shtml).

WRITING.TITLE: On CAH and treating pregnant women with dexamethasone

WRITING.TEXT: One of my favorites is [Charlie Jade](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Charlie_Jade). Unfortunately it was discontinued after one season, but is well worth a watch. Not your quick-pased action kind of deal, but I though it was extraordinarily well made.

To your second question; I feel it's a "damned if you do, damned if you don't" type of deals, I think. I would like to know, beforehand, if not for the moment of aw for it happening! Also, the cynic in me wouldn't want any sort of "interest" represent the human kind in secret. On the other hand, the day we get visitors from other planets, we're probably as doomed as most indigenous people that were around once "civilization" hit them, and perhaps it would be preferable to live yet another while in ignorant bliss... ;)

Well, if his point was to blame yourself, you have a valid point of course. However, I got the impression that he meant the opposite, like shit happens, nobody's truly evil, you need to move on, break the patterns that landed you in the mess in the first place. Like seeing you're a part of a problem, or something like that. I realize, when writing, that I can't be sure that's what he meant, a lot was said. Guess he was musing all over the place, and can be interpreted differently.
I interpreted it more like, even though somebody else is shelfish, you should avoid being it yourself. Kind of like, give yourself a chance not to repeat patterns, or whatnot.
En ibland de bsta frklaringar av ordet jag sett. Ryggdunk!

Well, to me it would seem that an element of doubt, has been introduced. Trying not to spoil, by Cameron has encountered a few things that makes her less "die hard" in mind, than I first assumed. So I'm guessing it's not going to be as cut and dry. Just speculating though.

Either way is fine, I reckon. I've got a box in the freezer that I use for it.

Always buy two pairs, and keep one pair in the freezer over night. This works for any type of shoes, really. Don't wait until they start to smell, start doing it straight away. (Also, my uncle swears by rinsin his feet with really cold water each morning, haven't tried that one myself though.)
In Sweden they announced that they aren't going to make anymore phonebooks. Which is fine by most, but have worried some of the seniors, of course, since they're generally not connected online.

Interestingly the word "apologetic" is usually used in cases to wave away responsibility for offenders, in one way or another. Like "it was a joke" when somebody's feelings get hurt, so I had a hard time understanding your point. I do forgive OP for comparing Tosh.0 with George Carlin though, it's never a bad thing getting a bit of George now and then.

Don't know if you already figured it out: The book from your first edit is written by Johan Arndt, a german lutheran. You can find more information on him on [wikipedia](http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Johann_Arndt). I wouldn't be surprised if there are english translations of his work floating around somewhere. //edit: The book in question would be "True Christianity", that is.
I found his first advice contradicting the rest. I truly agree with keeping advice on (or judge) how people should sort out their lives, to a minimum, if not shutting up about it completely.

Yes, he's got a great voice, but I'm also kind of surprised how few seem to have noticed the lyrics (I'm so glad you did, wolfbaden6) - which to me, is what sets this apart from anything I've heard in years. When reading the comments on youtube, and here, most seem to notice his voice, and I went all meta, thinking that perhaps the lyrics these days are so bad in general, that people stopped paying attention to the words. Like it's not expected to bring any value, not even worth reflecting or something.
I *did* get a bit suspicious when I saw "Sverigedrkten", but then again, it just seemed like the guy had no boundaries, so plausible. Great job, truly!
"My life as a dog" (Mitt liv som hund) Swedish movie, directed by Lasse Hallstrm, I think.
Gosh, that really made me sad as a kid. Still does.
Outrageous, finding out how to find a clitoris and how to touch it! Of all the upsetting things to find online...

Thanks, makes sense, there shouldn't be any problems relating to stats indeed. It confused me as I read the diskussion like it was about her lack of argumentative skills, that she was expected somehow to be able to argue the matter somehow. Thanks again!

Please forgive a (no doubt) clueless question; I'm confused by this thread. How is it that she is supposed to be able to argue in the matter? Does the DEA both decide and uphold the laws? Isn't it the politicians that propose and set laws in motion, that government organizations like the DEA uphold? Where I'm from (Sweden) a civil servant can defend/justify/argue laws if they want to, a bit of a problem sometimes though, in my view, when they do. As they're employed (i.e. not elected) to make sure the laws (right or wrong) are upheld, it might not always be prudent. If anybody could explain to me how this works in the US, I'd be grateful.
Varit rtt grejt idag - verkar bli sol till snapsen och grodorna!
Here's an article from 2010, where Ecuador [offers Assange residency](http://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-latin-america-11874911).

The karma system isn't going to change or anything - but I'm wondering if up- and downvotes didn't make a user karma-points, just sorting out the most voted on and least, if things would look different? It would be interesting with a karma-free week or something like that, where up- and downvotes merely affects what ends up on the front (or top comments), and doesn't count towards personal karma. I'm not sure really if anything would be different, being upvoted without actually keeping a score on your account, would probably still be a sort of achievement to many. Attention is a bit of a currency online in general, after all. Oh well, I guess regarding issues to worry about, the karma system of Reddit ranks pretty low when all is said and done, but I am kind of curious if people would post less.

My heart goes out to him and his family. However, I can't help but wonder who in his family/friends uploaded this to rake points online? Perhaps the police investigating the accident? In any case, that makes me almost as uneasy as the gut wrenching cries.

WRITING.TITLE: Need advice on how to keep the phone steady
WRITING.TEXT: I've more or less reached the conclusion that if I want truly qualitative cinemagraphs, I'm going to have to film with my system camera and be pixel-careful in photoshop. However, I really, really like the [spontaneity](http://s3.amazonaws.com/cine_1/9666903.gif) of using an app - seeing something and shooting it on a whim, just for fun. As much as my standard needs to be in alignment with the tool used, talent and time alotted, it really annoys me that it's so difficult to hold the phone steady. Do you guys have any tips on how to improve the steadyness (a word?) when using the phone?
Agreed - however, quality cinemagraphs are rather scarse, and this impressed me by it's how thought through it were.
Complaining ON the internet, no less.
